#â€‹673 â€” February 1, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Cytoscape.js: Graph/Network Visualization and Analysis Library â€” Handy if you need to model and/or visualize relational data, like biological data or social networks. There are many demos to enjoy here. GitHub repo.

Max Franz

Announcing TypeScript 5.4 Beta â€” TypeScript gains Object.groupBy and Map.groupBy, a new NoInfer<T> utility type is introduced to stop TypeScript from digging in to match against inner types during inference, and lots of smaller bits and pieces covered in this lengthy post. The final release is expected in March.

Daniel Rosenwasser

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript DataGrid â€” A fast and flexible DataGrid for building modern web apps. Key features and virtualized rendering are included in the grid module. Pick and choose special features to keep your app small. Built for JavaScript, extended to Angular, React, and Vue.

Wijmo from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Deno 1.40: Now with the Temporal API â€” Most releases of the Deno JS runtime seem significant lately, but 1.40â€™s implementation of the Temporal API, decorators, and more WebGPU features ups the ante on the path to v2.

The Deno Team

IN BRIEF:

  • Some Node.js security releases are anticipated next Tuesday (Feb 6.)

  • TIL: The pnpm project maintains a frequently updated benchmark of package managers (well, npm, pnpm and Yarn, anyway.)

  • ğŸ€ Bouncy Ball shows a live comparison of 22 ways to animate a bouncing ball in the browser. Most are JS-based and show the code.

  • Porffor is an experimental, ahead-of-time JS to WASM compiler.

RELEASES:

  • htmx 2.0.0-alpha1 â€“ There's a draft 1.xâ†’2.x migration guide showing what will be affected (not a lot).

  • Puppeteer 21.10.0 â€“ Node.js API for Chrome - now with experimental browser.debugInfo.

  • Neutralinojs 5.0 â€“ Lightweight cross platform desktop app framework.

  • Primate 0.28, Prisma 5.9, Ember 5.6, Pixi.js 7.4

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

Take a Qwik Break from React with Astro â€” Paul Scanlon compares React to Qwik using several examples and concludes that Qwik is at least worth exploring as a React alternative.

Paul Scanlon

Import Assertions and Import Attributes â€” Shu-yu Guo, of both TC39 and the V8 team at Google, explains how import assertions matured into import attributes and are enabled by default in V8 v12.3.

Shu-yu Guo (V8)

A Next.js App Router Migration: The Good, Bad, and Ugly â€” A team rebuilt their main dashboard from scratch using a modern Next.js approach and hereâ€™s some of what they encountered, good and bad, before concluding that they wish theyâ€™d considered Remix instead.

Brandon Bayer (Flightcontrol)

Improving Enterprise Design Systems â€” Live stream for design system builders and users: How can we make working with design systems more seamless?

StackBlitz sponsor

Squeezing the Last Bit of JS Performance for my Automation Game â€” The author is building CivIdle, a casual â€˜idleâ€™ civilization building game, using Pixi.JS. As an idle game, it needs to simulate time that passed behind the scenes which meant a lot of optimization was in order.

Ruoyu Sun

Starting and Publishing a Library: The Modern Way â€” A walk through the steps involved in creating and packaging a library, publishing a package, adding testing, and automatically publishing it all to the NPM registry.

TamÃ¡s Sallai

How to Test Web Bluetooth with Puppeteer â€” Use Puppeteer to test features that use the Web Bluetooth API in Chrome.

Masso and Beaufort

The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer Must Know About Unicode â€” A modern extension to a classic 2003 article by Joel Spolsky.
Nikita Prokopov

Tackling Flaky Tests with Cypress and Playwright through Network Synchronization
Shreya Kurian

Why I'm Excited for Biome's Type Inference
Arend van Beelen jr.

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Labyrinthos.js: A Procedural Generator for Mazes, Etc. â€” The interactive demo on the homepage will give you the basic idea, but the library implements a variety of algorithms for creating mazes and terrain, including the use of Perlin noise, growing trees, spiral backtracking, and more. GitHub repo.

Yantra Works

The Most Comprehensive User Management Platform â€” Clerk offers drop-in auth & user management with prebuilt UI components, feature-rich SDKs & APIs for the modern web.

Clerk sponsor

React Resizable Panels: Components for Resizable Panels â€” If you want users to be able to resize content panels with dividers, try this. The site has many code-based examples showing off the features. v2 supports resizing multiple intersecting panels at once. GitHub repo.

Brian Vaughn

Husky 9: Git Hooks Made Easier â€” Husky provides a structured way to use git hooks to do things like auto-lint your commit messages or code, and run tests upon committing or pushing. v9 makes setting it up and adding hooks much easier.

typicode

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Better JavaScript Shell Scripting with Bun Shell â€” Performance-focused server-side runtime Bun continues its rapid evolution with a side quest into the world of shell scripting by making it easier, cross-platform friendly, and less verbose. zx offers similar (but less integrated and focused) functionality to Node users, if you should prefer.

Jarred Sumner (Bun)

Announcing AdonisJS v6 â€” If you want a backend Web framework with amazing docs and packed with features, Adonis is a good choice. v6 is a big step forward moving to ESM by default, with more type safety overall (including for routes and middleware references), a new validation library, and more.

Harminder Virk

Learn Vite, The Fast Build Tool for Modern Web Projects â€” Join Steve Kinney for this video course tour of Vite's capabilities, including a look at bundling, optimizing static assets, hot module reloading, and its plugin ecosystem. You'll come away proficient at using Vite to build scalable, performant apps.

Frontend Masters sponsor

QuickJS: The Small, Embeddable JavaScript Engine â€” Several years ago, Fabrice Bellard, the genius behind FFMPEG and JSLinux, built a tiny and complete JavaScript engine in C. It now supports ES2023 and its latest release adds top-level await in modules and its REPL, as well as support for some cutting edge JS features (changelog).

Fabrice Bellard

IN BRIEF:

  • @npm_malware on Twitter/X shares malicious packages detected in real time.

  • JetBrains has opened up its Early Access Program for WebStorm 2024.1, its commercial JS/TS IDE.

  • ğŸ“… React Conf 2024 takes place this May 15-16 online and at Lake Las Vegas.

RELEASES:

  • Astro 4.2 â€“ The framework that never ceases to amaze.

  • Node.js 21.6.1 (Current) â€“ A bug fix for Undici.

  • Puppeteer 21.9 â€“ Now using Chromium 121.

  • Next.js 14.1, Qwik 1.4, Expo Router v3, Redux Toolkit 2.1

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

Web Components in Earnest â€” This is.. epic! If you want to really get a walk through the journey of building an entire app using Web Components and JavaScript, this is it. The app in this case is simple, but complete, and the author shows off the realities of going all in with Web Components here.

David Bryant Copeland

â–¶  An Alpine, HTMX, and Astro-Based Wordle App â€” Popular dev YouTuber Jack demonstrates building a Wordle clone with a modern Alpine, HTMX and Astro-based stack. Or you can go straight to the code, if you prefer.

Jack Herrington

Complete Your AI Coding Experience with Wallaby.js â€” Get instant test feedback and powerful debugging for AI code suggestions.

Wallaby Team sponsor

How to Start a React Project in 2024 â€” Robin explains the pros and cons of a few common approaches, including using Vite, Astro, and Next.js.

Robin Wieruch

Build a Next.js App in Storybook with React Server Components and Mock Service Worker â€” How to develop, document, and test RSC apps in isolation, while using MSW to mock network requests.

Michael Shilman

Reversing and Tooling a Signed Request Hash in Obfuscated JS
Brett Buerhaus

Create a Currency Converter with HTML, CSS, and Vanilla JavaScript
Esther Vaati

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Jint 3.0: A JavaScript Interpreter for .NET â€” Run JavaScript within a .NET app and expose .NET objects and functions to JavaScript code. v3 arrives after seven years of work and is the most standards-compliant JS engine running entirely within .NET.

SÃ©bastien Ros

Mutative: A Library for Efficient Immutable Updates â€” A library for efficient immutable updates, boasting being 2-6x faster than naive handcrafted reducers, and even more than 10x faster than Immer. GitHub repo.

Michael Lin

Auth Without Complexity â€” Authentication in a Straightforward Platform â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docs now.

Userfront sponsor

React Email 2.0: Build Better Emails with React â€” React Email is a collection of unstyled components for creating emails using JSX and React (this example shows you the basic idea).

Gabriel Miranda (Resend)

workerpool 9.1: Offload Tasks to a Pool of Workers â€” A long established thread pool library that works not only on Node but also in the browser.

Jos de Jong

Microsoft TypeSpec: A TypeScript-Inspired Way to Define APIs â€” A language for concisely describing cloud service APIs and generating other API description languages (e.g. OpenAPI), client and service code, docs, and more. Formerly known as CADL. â€“ GitHub repo.

Microsoft

Receive, Authenticate, Transform, Filter, Route, and Deliver Webhooks â€” The Hookdeck Event Gateway is a reliable platform to support event-driven application development across the full development lifecycle.

Hookdeck sponsor

Partytown 0.9: Run Third Party Scripts in a Web Worker â€” A way to run resource intensive scripts on a separate thread (in a web worker) to let the main thread remain responsive. GitHub repo.

Partytown

console.delight â€” You use console.log to output text, but did you know that in the browser console it can be used to render other things, like SVGs and HTML? This post is packed with examples and goes deeper into the creative options opened up by the technique than youâ€™ll probably ever need ğŸ˜…

Zach Saucier

The AHA Stack: Another Way to Build Modern Webapps â€” The AHA Stack is a full-stack webapp approach that brings together Astro, htmx, and Alpine.js, and where you send HTML over the wire. This is a fantastic showcase site that sells the idea well, complete with explanations and examples.

Flavio Copes

Transform the Way You Handle Forms with SurveyJS Form Libraries â€” With SurveyJS UI components you can set up a powerful form management system fully integrated into your IT. Effortlessly build, edit and style dynamic JSON-based forms in the drag & drop form builder with an integrated CSS-based theme editor.

SurveyJS sponsor

React Libraries for 2024 â€” The latest update of a popular, opinionated, annual guide to libraries and tools suitable for various tasks when building React apps, covering areas like state management, UI libraries, authentication, and testing.

Robin Wieruch

IN BRIEF:

  • htmx has just become 0 clause BSD-licensed. It was 2 clause BSD before â€“ the main change being attribution is no longer required on redistribution.

  • Yagiz Nizipli â–¶ï¸ went on the Syntaxâ€¤fm podcast to talk about all things JS performance related.

  • A showcase of what PWAs can do today.

  • A look at how to compile a standalone executable using modern JavaScript runtimes.

RELEASES:

  • Prettier 3.2 â€“ The popular code formatter gains support for JSONC and Angular ICU expressions.

  • Knip 4.0 â€“ Find and remove unused files and dependencies.

  • ReScript 11.0 â€“ OCaml-inspired, typed 'compile to JS' language.

  • Node.js v21.6.0 (Current)

  • Node.js v20.11.0 (LTS) â€“ Now with import.meta.dirname and import.meta.filename

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

The Golden Rule of Assertions â€” Artem shares a tip that helps him write better tests or, as he calls it, the â€˜Golden Rule of Assertionsâ€™: â€œA test must fail if, and only if, the intention behind the system is not met.â€

Artem Zakharchenko

â–¶  Let's Code Minesweeper in JavaScript â€” Ania is back with another of her fantastic step-by-step walkthrough videos. Now you can actually implement Minesweeper, rather than waste time playing it.. ğŸ˜

Ania KubÃ³w

JavaScript Frontend Error Monitoring 101 â€” Take a crash (pun intended) course on JavaScript error monitoring and debugging with Sentry. Read on.

Sentry sponsor

5 CSS Snippets Every Frontend Developer Should Know in 2024 â€” Adam did a similar roundup last year, now heâ€™s back with more toolbelt-worthy, powerful, CSS tips worth knowing.

Adam Argyle

Migrating from Zod to Valibot: A Comparative Experience â€” Zod and Valibot both provide a mechanism to validate data using types, and Matthew looks at how he found Valibot better for validating his contact form.

Matthew Kwong

A Difference Between getElementByID and querySelector â€” IDs with leading digits pose problems when it comes to CSS selectors.

Kiru from Switzerland

Kind of Annoyed at React â€” â€œJust a little ranty rant about my fave JS libraryâ€
Cassidy Williams

The Building Blocks of a Greenfield Vue App in 2024
Fotis Adamakis

Manually Dispatching an Event to a Target
Chris Coyier

Heat.js: A Heat Map Visualization Library â€” It has no dependencies, and is small, responsive, and themeable. GitHub repo.

William Troup

Some Top Frontend Tools of 2023 â€” Louis walks through a collection of tools that he found useful in the past year. It's a rather eclectic selection â€“ I certainly hadn't heard of many of them â€“ and you're sure to find some that could help in your day-to-day work.

Louis Lazaris

Drop-In Authentication & User Management for Next.js â€” Add auth in minutes with Clerkâ€™s prebuilt components, hooks, and helpers for Next.js 14.

Clerk sponsor

Tinybench: A Tiny, Simple Benchmarking Library â€” No dependencies â€“ it uses whatever timing capabilities are available (e.g. process.hrtime or peformance.now). You can then benchmark whatever functions you want, specify how long/how many times to benchmark, and get a variety of stats back.

Tinylibs

ğŸ›°  Orbital Object Toolkit: Orbital Mechanics Made Easier â€” This is miles above my paygrade (about 100 miles in fact) but if determining the positions of satellites and terms like â€˜SGP4 propagationâ€™ and â€˜TLE parsingâ€™ make sense to you..

Theodore Kruczek

worker-timers: setInterval/setTimeout for Unfocused Windows â€” When a tab loses focus, any timers used within can be throttled. A workaround is to use a Web Worker.

Christoph Guttandin

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Is htmx Just Another JavaScript Framework? â€” Despite being four years old, htmx has seen a surge in popularity recently, parly due to fatigue with 'big frameworks' and also because its simple HTML-based approach to adding functionality to a page appeals to an increasingly diverse group. But is it just another framework itself? Yes. And no.

Alexander Petros

â–¶  HTMX for React Developers in 10 Minutes â€” You're not interested in discussions about semantics.. you just want to get something done with htmx? Here, Jack takes ten minutes to show off the essentials.

Jack Herrington

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demos now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

33 JavaScript Concepts Every Developer Should Know â€” A curated collection of links to tutorials on 33 different areas worth understanding well, including: types, closures, equality, scope, and different engines. We linked this two years ago, but it remains frequently updated.

Leonardo Maldonado

Introducing fsx: A Modern Filesystem API for JavaScript â€” Filesystem APIs in JavaScript runtimes havenâ€™t been great for a long time. This is one prominent JavaScript expertâ€™s attempt to make a better one.

Nicholas C. Zakas

IN BRIEF:

  • CodePen shares its top 100 'pens' of 2023. Lots of fantastic bits and pieces to look through and learn from here.

  • Bored? The Deno team is running a little hackathon over the next week.

  • jsfree.org is a new effort to catalog web services that can work without JavaScript.

  • ğŸŒ¼ Enjoy the drawing.garden.

RELEASES:

  • Docusaurus 3.1 â€“ Popular site generator/framework.

  • Rspack 0.5 â€“ Fast Rust-based web bundler.

  • MikroORM 6 â€“ TypeScript ORM for Node.js.

  • Node.js v20.11.0 (LTS), Bun 1.0.22, npm 10.3 and Astro 4.1.

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

The Website vs. Web App Dichotomy Doesn't Exist â€” An interesting think piece that will help you flesh out your own opinions on the matter: â€œIf thereâ€™s one takeaway from all this, itâ€™s that the web is a flexible medium where any number of technologies can be combined in all sorts of interesting ways.â€

Jake Lazaroff

Rust-Based JavaScript Linters: Fast, But No Typed Linting Right Now â€” An explanation of why the speed gains from Rust-powered linters arenâ€™t comparable to the full feature set of typescript-eslint.

Josh Goldberg

Reduce 80%+ Latency with Vercel Edge Functions â€” Learn how TiDB Serverless + Vercel Edge Functions can significantly reduce latency for global users. Read now!

TiDB sponsor

The State of Benchmarking in Node.js â€” While Node has always been fast (thanks largely to its V8 underpinnings), thereâ€™s a renewed focus on performance in the face of benchmarks and claims from alternatives like Deno and Bun. Lars looks at the ecosystem of benchmarking options in the space.

Lars Kappert

A CSS Media Query for Scripting Support â€” A new media query (e.g. @media (scripting: none)) was just added to Chrome (and Edge) to let you to define styles upon whether scripting languages are available. It's supported in all major browsers now â€“ a rare case of Chromium playing catch-up!

Stephanie Stimac

â–¶  What is Remix Exactly? â€” As in Remix, the full-stack web framework.

Alem Tuzlak

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

zip.js: Library to Zip and Unzip Files â€” Sounds simple, and it is, but it supports a couple of different formats and can generate password protected ZIPs. There are a few demos, but the simplest one sold me on its own. GitHub repo.

Gildas Lormeau

Element Plus: Vue 3 Component Library â€” Out of the box you get a large variety of clean components with a minimal vibe. You can see them in action here.

Element Plus Team

Add Authorization, MFA, Biometrics and More to Your JavaScript App in Just Minutes â€” It's about time that somebody talked some sense about OAuth and JavaScript. So we did. You're welcome.

FusionAuth sponsor

RE2JS: Linear Time Matching for Regular Expressions â€” RE2 is a regex engine built by Google designed to operate in time proportional to the size of the input, in order to avoid so-called â€˜ReDoSâ€™ problems backtracking can cause. There are bindings for Node.js, but this version works in the browser.

Oleksii Vasyliev

Penrose: Beautiful Math Diagrams by Writing Plain Text â€” It might sound a little like Mermaid (indeed, their homepages are strikingly similar) but its scope feels somewhat more math-focused â€“ there are many examples.

Penrose Contributors

DOMPurify 3.0.8: A Fast, Tolerant XSS Sanitizer for HTML â€” Supports all modern browsers and is heavily tested. Thereâ€™s a live demo here.

Cure53

remoteStorage: Cross Browser/Device Persistence â€” Combines the localStorage API with a remote server to persist data across browsers and devices â€“ so basically, imagine localStorage but remote. Hereâ€™s the server part.

Frigade

  • eslint-plugin-vue 9.20.0 â€“ The official ESLint plugin for Vue.js now supports Vue 3.4. Homepage.

  • file-type 19.0 â€“ Detect file type from a Buffer, Uint8Array, or ArrayBuffer.

  • React Unity WebGL 9.5 â€“ Embed Unity WebGL builds in React apps.

  • htmlparser2 9.1 â€“ A fast and forgiving HTML/XML parser.

  • YouTube.js 8.2 â€“ Wrapper around YouTube's internal API.

  • React-PDF 7.7 â€“ React component to display PDFs.

  • HLS.js 1.5 â€“ HTTP Live Streaming client library.

  • React Icons 5.0 â€“ Easily use popular icons in React apps.

  • Chai 5.0 â€“ BDD / TDD assertion library.
